description: From Middle English exit, from Latin exitus (“departure, going out; way by which one may go out, egress; (figuratively) conclusion, termination; (figuratively) death; income, revenue”), from exeō (“to depart, exit; to avoid, evade; (figuratively) to escape; of time: to expire, run out”) + -tus (suffix forming action nouns from verbs). Exeō is derived from ex- (prefix meaning ‘out, away’) + eō (“to go”) (ultimately from ). The English word is cognate with Italian esito, Portuguese êxito, Spanish éxito. Doublet of ejido.
The verb is derived from the noun.

definitionGroups.group: An act of going out or going away, or leaving; a departure.

entries.meaning: (specifically, drama) The action of an actor leaving a scene or the stage.
An opening or passage through which one can go from inside a place (such as a building, a room, or a vehicle) to the outside; an egress.
examples: Antonyms: entrance, entranceway, entry, (archaic, rare) entryway, ingang, ingress, portal
He was looking for the exit and got lost.
She stood at the exit of the house looking back and waving at those inside.

entries.meaning: (road transport) A minor road (such as a ramp or slip road) which is used to leave a major road (such as an expressway, highway, or motorway).
(figuratively, often euphemistic) The act of departing from life; death.
examples: the untimely exit of a respected politician

verbs.description: exit (third-person singular simple present exits, present participle exiting, simple past and past participle exited)

definitionGroups.group: (intransitive) To go out or go away from a place or situation; to depart, to leave.

entries.meaning: (theater) To leave a scene or depart from a stage.
(intransitive, often euphemistic) To depart from life; to die.
(transitive, intransitive, computing) To end or terminate (a program, subroutine, etc.)

definitionGroups.group: (transitive, originally US, also figuratively) To depart from or leave (a place or situation).

entries.meaning: (transitive, specifically) To alight or disembark from a vehicle.
(bridge, intransitive) To give up the lead.
examples: West now plays a low club to the J and Q. North exits in a trump.

description: Borrowed from Latin exit, the third-person singular present active indicative of exeō (“to depart, exit; to avoid, evade; (figuratively) to escape; of time: to expire, run out”); see further at etymology 1 above.

entries.meaning: (intransitive, drama, also figuratively) Used as a stage direction for an actor: to leave the scene or stage.
